body: @merlimat can you comment as well

I think that the original PR kind of broke the semantic of the API (`newConsumer()` returning an actual consumer) and that causes the problems like in functions when running in thread runtime. That would probably be affecting other applications as well. 

Other than that, I think there would be a problem coming with unacked messages. 
 1. Consumer-1 gets M1
 2. Consumer-2 shares the same underlying "consumer"
 3. Closing Consumer-1 *will not* close the underlying consumer
 4. M1 will not be replayed to Consumer-2 as it was the case before the change.
ping @jerrypeng @sijie

run java8 tests
run integration tests

First of all, my apologise for the trouble. Please, let me clarify when this is happening.

A previously built consumer would be returned when the next union is met: Shared mode consumers on the same topic with the same subscription within the same pulsar client.

Previously to #3312 creating a new consumer with the previous mentioned characteristics would result in a waste of resource and wouldn't result in a truly more threaded consumer, if performance is wanted, I think the asynchronous api should be good enough.

Even so, if the same consumer is wanted to be created with this characteristics, in order to have truly more threaded consumer, you could do it with a new pulsar client instance provided.

> Other than that, I think there would be a problem coming with unacked messages.

Let me try to answer this with your example:

  1. Consumer-1 gets Message-1.
  2. Consumer-2 is created but Consumer-1 is returned.
  3. Consumer-1 receive close(), but won't close the consumer in fact.
  4. Consumer-2 is still alive, and any redelivery will still be made.
  5. Consumer-2 receive close(), this time really closing the consumer.

The key here is that Consumer-2 actually never exists, all the time was the same Consumer-1 doing the work.
Anyway, if you like, I can add a test in order to assert this scenario and verify this for real.

Keep in mind that if we revert #3312 the issue #3226 will come again to the surface.

I think #3743 was attempting to revert to the change and #3746 comes up a fix with reference counting. If reverting, we need to revert all related changes. So I would suggest holding a bit on reverting. Let’s discuss it to see if there is any other fixes. If there is no, I am fine with reverting all the changes.

For the issue that functions is facing, I think it comes from MessageListener. Because if consumers are using receive and receiveAsync, the messages should be spreading across the instances calling the methods of a same consumer. So the fix for this issue can be:

1) add the support for multiple message listeners.

Or 

2) set the consumer name in functions.

Regarding the semantic question Matteo raises, I don’t know how to address his concern.

Regarding the unack redeliver behavior, the unacked messages will still be redeliverd to consumer-2 when ack time-out happens.

> Regarding the unack redeliver behavior, the unacked messages will still be redeliverd to consumer-2 when ack time-out happens.

That is only true if ack-timeout is enabled, but that is not the default behavior (because we cannot establish a "default" max processing time).

In the default case, the message received by application will stay unacked.
Alternatively we can return a wrapper consumer of the reference counted consumer. Although I am not sure if there are any problems around this approach.

> That is only true if ack-timeout is enabled, but that is not the default behavior (because we cannot establish a "default" max processing time).

That’s true.
idk if is a good solution but unsubscribe() instead of close() would finish the consumer on the first try.

@sijie in regards to how this impacts functions, even if we change PulsarSource to call receive() or add multiple message listener support , it still causes nondeterministic behavior when creating functions using ThreadRuntime.  Multiple attempts at creating the same function with the same number of instances will yield different number of consumers.  This creates a nightmare when trying to debug functions

@jerrypeng for functions, does it make better to set a consumer name (e.g. instance-<instance-if>-consumer) for both debugging and addressing the problem? Hence at broker side, if you are using stats, you know which consumer has problem. At client side, it should have returned a brand new consumer instance if a different consumer name is used. I forgot if current code can do that or not. If not, maybe that’s a simple fix to go first with setting a unique consumer name in functions.

@sijie I just tested with consumers with consumer name set as UUIDs, yet they still get returned as the same instance.  Though that just maybe be a bug. 

We currently do set consumer meta data to indicate which function and instance this consumer is from which should be enough info for debugging purposes.

+1 to adding consumer name to resolve the functions issue.
As for the optimization issue, I think it breaks the newConsumer() abstraction in a fundamental way.

subscription name instead of consumer name was added in order to identify duplicated consumers.

> I think it breaks the newConsumer() abstraction in a fundamental way.

It breaks in the same way a singleton class does, and anyway it's used extensively in a lot of places.

> subscription name instead of consumer name was added in order to identify duplicated consumers.

if that is the case, then there is no way for functions to side step this problem and we will have to revert the change because functions need to have to ability to create consumers using the same subscription
@merlimat Finally got all the tests passing. Should be good to go.

Isn't possible for functions just to share the consumer instance instead of create multiple of the same?

Also, maybe we can modify #3312 to use consumer name instead of subscription name, idk if we will break issue #3226 with that.
@jerrypeng I've just made #4139 in order to address what you need.

@sijie Oh, well, wasn't this what was proposed in the issue?

I removed `Fix #4137` from the description. since this change doesn't fix the whole problem of #4137. It only addresses the concerns in functions. We still need discussions in #4137 to address other concerns.
run java8 tests

> In the default case, the message received by application will stay unacked.

Hence, maybe the feature we don't want is #3795?
@sijie Sure, I'll review it soon.

> idk if is a good solution but unsubscribe() instead of close() would finish the consumer on the first try.

Unsubscribe is a different operation from close. It will actually remove the subscription and stop retaining data.

> for functions, does it make better to set a consumer name (e.g. instance--consumer) for both debugging and addressing the problem? 

@sijie Functions are already setting the consumer properties so they can be identified in the topic stats.

>> I think it breaks the newConsumer() abstraction in a fundamental way.

> It breaks in the same way a singleton class does, and anyway it's used extensively in a lot of places.

The problem is that the semantic of newConsumer() implies you're going to create a new "consumer" resource. If you're returning a cached object, the semantic is different. Application relying on the existing semantic will be broken.

> Isn't possible for functions just to share the consumer instance instead of create multiple of the same?

Functions with thread-runtime need to be able to manage the lifecycle of each consumer independently. This is a perfectly valid use of the API and was working correctly before. Similarly as functions, other application may be relying on the same API contract. 

> Hence, maybe the feature we don't want is #3795?

Without that, a consumer calling close() will cause all other consumers to stop receiving messages

I don't think that using the consumer name instead of the subscription name will solve the fundamental issue here. 

There are different problems: 
 1. Consumer name is randomly assigned if empty, so the caching will not take effect
 2. If application specifies same consumer name, then caching happen but: 
    a. Unacked messages will not be redelivered
    b. 1 or more consumers will be created, depending on race condition
    c. Consumer might actually have different configuration or metadata properties that are reported in topics stats
    d. There are issues with cached consumers using message listener (as the functions consumers are doing)

With all the downsides and the breaking of existing semantics, I don't see the need for consumers caching optimization. 

There is no problem is using multiple consumer from a same client instance. It does not impact performance or efficiency. 

If an application is requesting to create multiple consumers, that would be a valid use of the API. If an application has a bug and keeps creating new consumers, then the broker should protect itself and deny new consumers after a certain time.
Alright, @sijie I added a getCurrentMessage() method (I think in line with your approach 2).
@rdhabalia Would it be possible to happen for consumer creations too? (even in slightly different form)

OK,I will change these
I wiil work on this issue

> Without that, a consumer calling close() will cause all other consumers to stop receiving messages

And isn't that what is meant to be in this case?

> Consumer name is randomly assigned if empty, so the caching will not take effect

Yes, that's why at a first instance subscription name was chosen to verify duplicate consumers.

Agree with @Matteo that this optimizations maybe is not worth it just to fix issue #3226, maybe we can found a more easier solution to #3226 issue.

Since this optimizations seems to cause a lot of pain I made pull #4142 which reverts the entire feature and all related code to it, so you can decide the best path.

Apologies to all of you for the trouble.

>> Without that, a consumer calling close() will cause all other consumers to stop receiving messages

> And isn't that what is meant to be in this case?

But if you have 2 threads trying to use a consumer each: 
 1. T1 subscribes and gets C1
 2. T2 subscribes and gets C2
 3. If C1 == C2 (same instance)
     a. T1 closes C1
     b. T2 gets exception on the next receive()

Here each thread has the expectation that it gets a consumer and it will be valid until it gets explicitly closed.

Agree in that, but because of this ref count was implemented, I still don´t understand which use case within ref count on close() is broken. 

The user expecting the consumer to be closed but the consumer still retaining messages (default redelivery disabled) ?

@srkukarni 

Current presto integration bypasses Pulsar's schema's implementation and interacts with *avro schema data* directly. It introduces several problems:

1) all the *properties* are lost when presto gets splits.
2) it doesn't handle schema versions properly. 
3) it introduces a lot of duplicated code that has already been implemented in pulsar schema. it makes maintenance very hard.

Hence I don't think we should continue using the current approach for supporting other schema types. 

This is a WIP for demonstrating the approach I mentioned in #4022 to supporting primitive types in Presto.
/cc @codelipenghui and @congbobo184 since they are the main force developing the recent schema changes.
closed it as in favor of #4142

@wolfstudy did you get a chance to fix the integration tests?

@ConcurrencyPractitioner @sijie @srkukarni 

Approaches I thought of:


1. If we don't want to pull in pulsar-client-api and we want to the users to be able to get all of the properties of a Message<T>, then we will have to add the corresponding methods to the Record interface to expos all the properties.  

Pros: pulsar-function-api do not need to depend on pulsar-client-api

Cons: As @sijie mentioned before, we need properties/methods are add to Message<T>, we will also need to add them to the Record interface.  However, my biggest concern with this approach is that we already have methods like ``` getRecordSequence``` in the Record interface (which is different then the message sequence id though they return different forms of the same thing).  We will have to add another method getSequenceId to the Record interface which will be confusing.  Thus, I am not for this method

2. We add an additional method to PulsarRecord i.e. ```public Message<T> getRawMessage()```.  Add an method to the Context interface i.e. ```pubic Message<T> getRawInputMessage```.  In the implementation of the method, we will just cast Record to PulsarRecord which is assumed for functions anyways.

Pros: Simple addition

Cons: pulsar-function-api need to depend on pulsar-client-api. Though this is not a deal breaker for me.
@jerrypeng have you checked my initial proposal? the approaches you mentioned are not the proposal I proposed initially in #4110
@sijie want is your point?

my original proposal provides a cleaner approach. we don't have to deal with the pulsar-client-api and pulsar-function-api dependency and people doesn't have to cast to an PulsarRecord to get the actual message.  Things are handled properly and gracefully.

@sijie first of all I am not proposing user's casting Record -> PulsarRecord.  We can do that internally in the implementation and just return to the user the Message interface.  

@sijie the approach you suggest will still require the user to pull in the pulsar-client-api.
@sijie I am also ok will your approach if everyone one else is onboard
